utterance: SS: Hi, everyone. Shama Sharada from USC. I've been here in the chemical engineering department for about four years now. My area is catalyst design, and this spans molecular, heterogeneous, and photocatalysts using quantum chemistry and ab initio molecular dynamics.

utterance: AB: So I'm Ananya Renuka Balakrishna, and I'm an assistant professor in the mechanical engineering department. I joined last year, and it's my first time at the Salah conference. So in our research, we develop predictive mathematical models, for example, phase field methods, where we use this modeling technique to understand the links between microstructure and material properties. We're also interested in understanding the kinetics of some of the microstructural evolution and how this affects how a material responds to an external stimuli. And in the context of this conference, we are interested to sort of develop continuum scale models to understand the fundamentals of absorption process, competing diffusion mechanisms, and how this affects material properties that are used for absorption and storage.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Ananya explains her research area, including specific modeling techniques like phase field methods, and their application in understanding material properties and responses to stimuli.
annotations.present new idea: Ananya introduces her research focus on developing continuum scale models for understanding absorption processes and diffusion mechanisms, which hasn't been previously mentioned in the conversation.

utterance: AV: Welcome. Next on my screen is Carlos.

annotations.assign_task: Alex assigns the next introduction to Carlos, indicating it is his turn to speak.
annotations.encourage_participation: Alex is encouraging participation by inviting Carlos to introduce himself.

utterance: CMG: Hello. My name is Carlos Morales. I'm an assistant professor in chemical and biomolecular engineering at UCLA. I have been here for three years, and my lab works in the understanding of mass transport coupled to intrinsic kinetics. And the idea is that if we can decouple mass transport from intrinsic kinetics, then those intrinsic kinetics will be much more useful for, for people that do theory at the nano scale. And we are also trying to work on, on something as dimensionless analysis so that we can scale up these processes and, and in the process close the gap between centimeter, millimeter, and, and nano scale.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Carlos explains his research area, focusing on decoupling mass transport from intrinsic kinetics to make the latter more useful for theoretical nanoscale studies and using dimensionless analysis for scaling up processes and bridging scales.
annotations.present new idea: Carlos introduces his lab's focus on dimensionless analysis to scale up processes and close the gap between centimeter, millimeter, and nanoscale.

utterance: CM: So I was thinking I do I'm experimentalist and I use some modeling but I do not do modeling and I just want to know, is there anyone else who do experiments here or not?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Carlos asks if there are other experimentalists in the group, seeking to identify others with similar research approaches.

utterance: CM: So, I wanted to start maybe by by pointing out that maybe this is actually a challenge that many times it's sort of two different silos. And then it turns out that I think people that do theory trust that people that do experiments do the experiments in a controlled manner and that we have a good understanding of the types of reactors that we use. And if you actually ask experimentally, very likely they have very little understanding of what is the mass transport inside of those sort of systems and how that couples to kinetics. And then so you're essentially left trying to justify some experimental observations when the experimental observations and are really deviated from from it's affected simply by the geometry of the reactor. So that's where this I'm interested in this multiscale modeling, right? I would like to to see theory that is I read papers and sometimes they they have a big component of theory, but I do not really learn a lot because it matches the results and you say yes, this will explain them, right? And I think every time that I see thermodynamics, I'm okay with the calculations. When I see the use of DFT to do kinetics, that's when I start to see a lot of red flags because many times I think we don't even understand the reactors are where used. So, I don't know if that contributes to the discussion, but

present new idea: Carlos introduces the challenge of differing perspectives between experimentalists and theorists regarding reactor conditions and mass transport's impact on kinetics.
provide supporting evidence: Carlos supports his point about experimentalists' limited understanding of mass transport by stating that experimental observations can be significantly affected by reactor geometry.
explain or define term or concept: Carlos explains his interest in multiscale modeling to bridge the gap between theoretical calculations and experimental observations, especially concerning the influence of reactor design on kinetics.
offer constructive criticism: Carlos critiques the application of DFT calculations for kinetics due to the frequent lack of understanding of reactor conditions in theoretical studies.
encourage particpationin: Carlos invites further discussion by asking if his points contribute to the conversation.

utterance: AV: I think it's a very important point that you're making, right? So being able to compare apples to apples or pairs to pairs or whatever you want to call between experiment and theory is crucial because there will always be errors both in experiments and in theory. I mean, like this is not like we're doing science, but nothing is really the absolute truth in the end because we're continuing and it's changing over time, right? So at each point, we just need to ask ourselves, are we comparing the same things, right? And what what is needed in a model or in an experiment? What is in the experiment that the model needs to actually take into account, right? And that's not always clear, and we always oversimplify, right? So how do you, as you ask, how do you bridge the gaps between these two communities to actually be able to do appropriate comparisons. I if that if that's my interpretation of what you is that correct?

utterance: CM: So in many of the I do electrocatalysis. And then you will think that many of these electrochemical cells should be considered isothermal. In reality, these are adiabatic systems. Because assumption is, yeah, is in equilibrium with the outside, with the room where you're doing the experiment. But in reality, if you look at the thickness of the walls of the reactor, that's not the case. It's closer to an adiabatic system. And then if it's an adiabatic system, you have the energy needs to come from somewhere, right? So the over potential perhaps is doing that in in many of the electrochemical transformations. utterance: SM: I think one of the ways in which, like, at least the computational community can police itself in terms of whether we are predicting the properties correctly or not. Not necessarily accurately, but whether we are capturing the physics right or not, uh, is essentially by not worrying about the physical quantity as such, but, but to see if trends match what you see in experiment or what you believe to be correct through intuition, right? So if I, like, if I'm looking at a molecular system, for example, if I tweak the electrophilicity of one particular group at one end, I have some intuition about how that would impact the resulting kinetics. So to a certain extent, we can give meaningful results even though the underlying method does not capture, let's say, for example, charge transfer states.

annotations.present new idea: SM proposes a way for the computational community to evaluate models by focusing on matching trends observed in experiments or derived from intuition, rather than precise numerical accuracy.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Building on the prior discussion about the challenges of comparing computational models to experiments, SM suggests a method to assess the validity of computational models even with inherent simplifications.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: SM provides an example of tweaking the electrophilicity of a molecular system and using intuition to anticipate the impact on kinetics, illustrating how trend analysis can be more informative than absolute values.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: SM clarifies the distinction between predicting properties "correctly" (capturing the underlying physics) and "accurately" (achieving precise numerical agreement with experiments).

annotations.offer constructive criticism: Emily critiques the limitations of qualitative modeling, pointing out that it's often insufficient for the broader scientific community that prefers quantitative comparisons.
